questions.question: What does Table 1 include?
questions.ground_truth: Wear depth per wear case (export table text for precise values)

questions.question: What does Figure 1 illustrate?
questions.ground_truth: Tooth image progression from healthy to severe wear

questions.question: How many wear cases were tracked in total?
questions.ground_truth: 35 wear cases (W1-W35) plus the Healthy baseline case
questions.notes: Found in Table 1 wear severities dimensions

questions.question: What is the relationship between wear progression and vibration characteristics?
questions.ground_truth: As wear progresses from mild to severe, there is an increase in broadband vibration levels and the appearance of transient impulsive responses, indicating deteriorating gear condition

questions.question: Why was the sampling frequency set to 50 kHz?
questions.ground_truth: To capture high-frequency vibration components and gear mesh frequencies for detailed analysis of gear condition

questions.question: What are the implications of the 18/35 transmission ratio for gear wear analysis?
questions.ground_truth: The 18/35 ratio creates specific gear mesh frequencies that can be monitored for changes indicating wear progression

questions.question: What was the duration of the wear monitoring period?
questions.ground_truth: From February 13 (installation) to June 15 (failure) - approximately 4 months

questions.question: What happened during the April 9 measurement?
questions.ground_truth: First onset of wear was detected through microscope tooth photographs, corroborated by vibration changes

questions.question: What was the progression timeline from healthy to failure?
questions.ground_truth: Healthy → Mild wear (April 9) → Moderate wear (April 23) → Severe wear → Complete failure (June 15)
